newsitem.title: UK: Pre-election jitters hit UK economy - marketers.
newsitem.headline: Pre-election jitters hit UK economy - marketers.

text.p: Pre-election nerves are hitting British consumer spending and slowing down the economy, the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM) said in its quarterly state of the market report.
It said its forecasts for consumer spending growth for 1997 were lower than for 1996 in the three categories of durables, non-durables and services.
"The slowdown in consumer spending is a clear indicator of a weakening in the economy in the run-up to the election," the Institute's economic adviser Douglas McWilliams said.
"Even though a Labour victory is widely expected, there is still uncertainty about the policies a Labour government might follow."

However, the CIM said it expected the weakening in the economy to be short-lived, with consumer spending picking up after the election as consumers receive windfalls from the conversion of several building societies into banks.
The CIM's comments followed a weaker than expected CBI distributive trades survey for February last week, which economists said may have reflected pre-election uncertainty.
The institute said the weakening in the economy was not universal and construction appeared to have picked up strongly.
"Overall, the outlook is good for business investment, with growth predicted at 4.5 percent this year, rising to 7.4 percent by 1999," the CIM said.
Exporters faced a gloomy short-term outlook, with margins continuing to be slashed due to the strength of the pound.
But better news could be on the horizon by 1998 as some European economies should start to recover, the CIM said.
